374.
BENJAMIN MORTLOCK (42) and
BRIDGET MORTLOCK (37)
, Feloniously having in their possession certain moulds impressed with the obverse and reverse sides of a shilling.

MR. POLAND Prosecuted; MR. ROBERTSON Defended. BENJAMIN MORTLOCK
PLEADED GUILTY**. —
Ten Years' Penal Servi
tude .
On behalf of the female prisoner a certificate of her marriage with the male prisoner was produced, and evidence showing their cohabitation for many years, given upon which she was Acquitted.

375.
FRANK MOORE (22)
, Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

ELIZABETH MEAGOCK . I am the wife of Edward Meacock, of 6, Ex
change Buildings, East Dulwich Road, confectioner—on Wednesday, 6th February, about 5.30 or 6, the prisoner came in for two penny cheese
cakes; he took out a quantity of silver and threw a half
crown towards me; I gave him 2s. 4d. change—as he was leaving I found it was bad—I ran round the counter, and he ran away; the butcher next door ran after him—on the Friday evening I went to the station, and picked him out of seven or eight others—I gave the coin to the constable.

HANNAH BYRNE . I am the wife of Thomas George Byrne; he keeps the Helen's Head Tavern, in Norfolk Street, Peckham—on Thursday, 9th February, between 4 and 5, the prisoner came for a glass of sixpenny ale; he gave me a half
crown; I gave him 2s. 4d. change—he drank the ale and left—I put the half
crown in the till, and afterwards in my watch pocket—I found it was bad about ten minutes after the prisoner left—I kept it by itself, and afterwards gave it to the constable—I saw the prisoner on the following Wednesday at Lambeth and recognised him. ALEXANDER AUGUSTUS ELPHINSTONE STONE. I live at 15, Cambridge Terrace, Peckham, and am in the Civil Service—on Thursday, 9th Feb., about a quarter to 5, the prisoner came for 3s. worth of penny stamps—he gave me a good shilling and a bad half
crown—I told him I should detain him—the postmaster asked him where he got it—he said "I had it among other money for selling jewellery"—the postmaster asked where—he made no reply—a constable was called, I gave him the half
crown, and the prisoner was given into custody—I afterwards tried the half
crown with acid; it was bad—I believe the prisoner was there the week previous, when I served him with 3s. 6d. worth of penny stamps, and he gave me a half
crown and a shilling—I put that money in the till—there was no other half
crown there—about a quarter of an hour after he was gone I took it out and found it was bad—I had taken no other in the mean time—I gave it to the constable.

FBANK PULBBOOK (Policeman P 398). The prisoner was given into my custody on 9th February for uttering a bad half
crown at the post
office—I asked how he got it—he said he got it with other silver in hawking jewellery—I asked where—he said he did not know—I asked where he lived—he said" I have no home; I slept at a coffee-house last night"—I asked what he wanted the stamps for—he said for a friend he owed money to, C. Morris, 20, Market Street, Borough Road, and he lived there also—he was searched at the station, and 2s. in silver and 3 1/2 d. in bronze found on him, good money—I went to 20, Market

Street, and found it was a correct address—I afterwards received these two other half
crowns from Mr. Stone; he said in the prisoner's presence that he believed he was the man who uttered the half
crown in the week previous—the prisoner made no reply—the Helen's Head Tavern is about 230 yards from Victoria Road.
WILLIAM WEBSTER . These three coins are bad, and from different moulds.
ELLEN WEBSTER . I am married—the prisoner is my brother—on 8th February he was at my house at 3 in the afternoon, and he left at 9 o'clock.

Cross-examined. I live at 3, William Street, New Road—my husband is a fireman—the prisoner lived in the Borough—I gave evidence before the Magistrate—the prisoner was in the habit of coming to see me—I had not seen him for some long time—I know it was on Wed
nesday, 8th February, that he came, because he stopped till my husband came home—I heard that he was in custody next morning.
GUILTY .

He then PLEADED GUILTY to a previous conviction at this Court in September, 1859, of a like offence.—
Two Years' Hard Labour.

376.
JOSEPH VALLER (18) was indicted
for a like offence. MR. POLAND Prosecuted; MR. LILLEY Defended.

MARY ANN JOHNSON . I am the wife of John Johnson, a confectioner at Stock well Green—on Friday, 27th January, between 12 and 1, the prisoner came for a bottle of lemonade, price 2d.—he gave me a half
crown; I gave him change—he drank the lemonade, and went out—I kept the half
crown separate from other money till my husband came home in the evening, and then found it was bad—I afterwards gave it to a constable—I saw the prisoner again at Lambeth Police-court on the following Wednesday—there were seven or eight others in the room—I picked him out—to the fullest of my belief he is the man.

Cross-examined. He gave me the coin in a hurry, and went out in a hurry—he might be there a minute and half or two minutes—I had never seen him before—a policeman came and asked me about the case, and told me there was a young man in custody—he did not say what sort of man he was—I pointed him out at once, and said "That is the man. "

HENRY COLES . I am a baker, of 45, Ackerman Road, Brixton, about half a mile from Stock well Green—on Friday, 27th January, about 1.30, the prisoner came for two sponge cakes, and gave me a half
crown—I tried it and found it bad—I said to the prisoner "I think it is a bad one;" he said" Oh, is it?"—he said he would give me two penny pieces; he did so—I kept the half
crown, and took it to the front of the counter and said I should charge him—he ran out, I ran after him 200 or 300 yards; I caught him, and said "You must come back"—I took him back with assistance, and gave him into custody—this (produced) is the half
crown.
Cross-examined. When I stopped him he said he had no idea it was bad—he had some other silver in his possession.

ALBERT PEDDER (Policeman W 409). The prisoner was given into my custody by Mr. Coles—I said "Have you any more silver?" he said" Yes," and produced a good half
crown, a florin, six shillings, sixpence,

and a penny—I produce the half
crown I got from Mr. Coles, and another which I got from Mrs. Johnson.

Cross-examined. When I charged him he said he did not know it was bad. WILLIAM WEBSTER. These two half
crowns are bad, and from the same mould. The prisoner received a good character.

GUILTY. Recommended to mercy by the Jury .—
Four Months' Hard Labour.

377.
STEPHEN JONES (44),
CHARLES GREENWOOD (25),
THOMAS GREY (33), and
ROBERT CUMMINGS (79)
, Feloniously having possession of a mould resembling the obverse and reverse sides of a half
crown.

MESSRS. POLAND and HORACE AVORY Prosecuted; MR. GEOHRGAN appeared for Jones, and MESSRS. RIBTON and SMYTHIES for Greenwood. WILLIAM CHAMBERLAIN (Police Inspector L). In the beginning of January last I commenced keeping observation upon 19, Warple Way, Wandsworth—I have seen persons go in and out once or twice, and I instructed others to watch—on 31st January, about 6 p.m., I went there with Inspector Shaw and other constables—Shaw and I went in first, followed by four or five officers—a little girl came out and we popped in, when we saw the door on the jar—we went into the ante-room at the top of the stairs—Shaw went in first; I followed him—Grey and Cummings rushed past me—I saw Greenwood in the act of getting up from a table or from a box that was set up endways and used as a table—I saw a row of half
crowns lying—I afterwards counted, and found 101 counterfeit half
crowns and 80 florins—I saw a bright fire burning, and batteries and a naphtha lamp, which was burning, and a number of jars at the back and plaster
of
Paris moulds—we counted and brought away 100 broken and 19 unbroken moulds—I saw a quantity of metal, and the ladle produced was just taken off the fire—one ladle was full of molten metal—there was metal in the ashes of the fireplace, and a little block of metal near the mould; it had just been poured out of the ladle on to the block—we burnt our fingers—we found also a quantity of copper wire, some sheets of glass, and iron bands such as would go round these moulds in making them—a quantity of plaster
of
Paris, some mixed ready to pour into the mould, and a bag of sand—candles were burning—a thick blind was at the window, so that no one could see from the next house, and a sheet was across the door, so that one would not see them at first—these moulds for half
sovereigns and the two coun
terfeit half-sovereigns were found as well—Shaw took charge of Green
wood—Jones was brought in by Boswell about 10 minutes afterwards—I said to Jones "You are the landlord of the house?" he said" Yes"—I pointed to the coins which we had not touched, and said "How do you account for all these counterfeit coins which you have in this way?" he said" You know you have got us all right, what is the good of saying anything?"—I told the officers to search him; one took hold of each side; a purse was handed to me—I opened it—I counted 10 coins over to him—I said" I can see these have been used as patterns for making the moulds"—six half
crowns had been used as patterns and four florins—five shillings were also in the purse which had been used as patterns, also 4l. 10s. in gold—I pointed out that this money had been used, and

Jones said "All right" a second time—I searched every room in the house—Jones's wife and two or three little children were in the house—Mrs. Jones showed me something, in consequence of which I did not take her into custody—I had seen Greenwood and Jones go in and come out of a public-house kept by a Mr. Hill.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOHEGAN. There are four rooms and the ante
room in the house, two floors—another man was brought to me with Jones—he was detained till 12 or 1 at night—he was Jones's nephew—Mr. Eedwood is the landlord—there were seven half
crown moulds, about 12 florin moulds—some were double and treble moulds—I made a list at Wandsworth Police-court—I remembered when I made my note that Jones said "All right" when I said the coins were used for patterns—when my evidence was read over the Clerk said it was quite sufficient—we gave it as short as we could—the public-house is 150 or 200 yards from the coining place.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. I saw Greenwood as he was getting up—I did not see him sitting down—I know nothing against him—the ground
floor was roll of shavings—there were one or two mattresses there—there might be four—they appeared to be finished—I saw no workmen's tools; I did not search for them—I saw a barrow outside the house.

Cross-examined by Cummings. There was sufficient room for you to pass me in the passage—I called the constables up from below, not you. EDWARD SHAW (Police Inspector V), I went with Chamberlain to this house—I went into the ante
room—I saw Greenwood sitting by the table, and Cummings and Grey by the side of him—Grey and Cummings rushed out of the room—I caught hold of Greenwood by the collar with my left hand—he said "Don't hit me"—I said "No"—he had one of these coins in his hand—I do not know whether it was a half
crown or two
shilling piece—it was wet with a solution—I dropped it at once, and burnt my finger—it burnt me as an acid—I took Greenwood into the baok room on the first floor—I found on him 26 shillings and a sixpence good money—I believe there was a barrow outside the front door—I did not watch the house; I only gave directions.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. I could not say whether it was half a crown or a two
shilling piece that I found in Greenwood's hand—if I said at the police-court it was half a crown that is correct—he did not show it to me; I had to open his hand—he showed his hand to the Magistrate—there might have been a pair of mattresses in the room—I did not give him any beer at the station—I did not say I had seen him at work at the shavings—I was not present when any beer was given to him—I do not remember finding a railway-ticket on him—I found no tweezers—he gave a correct address to Goddard.
Cross-examined by Cummings. I saw you rush by—I saw you and Grey in the room when these things were found.

FREDERICK GRAY (Policeman L 176). I went with the other officers to this house on 31st January—I took Cummings into custody—he was standing in the doorway of the back room upstairs—I searched him at once—I found a sovereign, 3s. 6d. in silver, and 4d. in bronze, all good money—in his left
hand waistcoat pocket I found a good sovereign—I detained him while the search was being made in the house.

Croos
examined by Grey. I saw you upstairs against the ante
room.
Cross-examined by Cummings. I did not hear Chamberlain say "Send that man upstairs from below. "

GEORGE DAYBORNE (Policeman W R). I went to this house with the other officers—I saw Grey in the front room on the first floor—that is a bedroom—I searched him—I found this leather purse; it contained a good shilling, 9 1/2 d. in copper, and a bad florin—I said "You will be charged with being concerned with the others in manufacturing counter
feit coin"—he made no reply—I detained him while the house was being searched—he said several times "I want to go down to complete an order"—he did not say what the order was—he appeared sane—he was afterwards taken to the station and charged.

FRANCIS BOSWELL (Detective L). I was with the other officers—I saw them go in the house—after that I went to the Princess of Wales public-house, about 300 yards from No. 19—I saw Jones there—I know him personally—I called him outside, and said "I want to speak to you"—he said" Yes"—I said "You know me; let us go down to the house"—when we got to the house I told him I was a detective officer, and that other officers were in charge of his house—he made no reply—I searched him—I found a purse, which I handed unopened to Chamber
lain, who opened it and drew my attention to some coins that were inside—I had watched this house and the prisoners too since the early part of December—I know the other prisoners, except Cummings—I have seen them go in and out of No. 19, Warple Way, about a dozen times—I have seen Jones and Greenwood together—they have come out of the house—I have followed them to London—they entered the railway
station apart, and one of them fetched a cab and they drove to another railway
station—I followed them to a house in a small street in Soho—I had not seen them go the whole way to London before; they used to break off—I have seen them when they have got there—I have seen a mattress up against the window in Warple Way which any one at a distance would take for a blind—if the mattress was not there you could see into the room—I have not seen any mattresses taken away from the house.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOHEGAN. I saw Jones and Greenwood come to London on 22nd January—they went to a public-house named the Red or the Black Bull—I have followed the men and have been in their company drinking in the bar—after they left the house they went home—I did not take the person into custody who was talking to Jones in the Pincess of Wales—I believe he was detained—I do not know who detained him—I said at the police-court I told him I was a detective when we were near the house.
Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. I searched no part of the house, I only searched Jones—I began to watch the house about the first week in December, but I cannot name the date.

HARRY DIDHAMS (Detective V). I kept observation on this house, 19, Warple Way, for about a fortnight before the capture on 31st January—I have seen all the prisoners there—no other man—they have generally gone in singly and come out apart—Jones and Greenwood generally came out together—I have also seen them in the first
floor front room all together sitting at tea—I have seen them go in and out almost every day.
Cross-examined by MR. GEOHEGAN. I have seen a woman and some children going in and out.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. I attended at the police-court—I was not called—I found a mattress in the back room of the ground floor, not in the front room—I saw no tools or trestles for putting mattresses on—the house was searched—there was a quantity of shavings—a search was made amongst the shavings but nothing was found.

EDWARD REDWOOD . I am an auctioneer at Walworth—I let the house, 19, Warple Way, to Jones, about the beginning of November, 1881—I did not ask his Christian name—I collected the rent every week at the house—not more than twice from Jones—I think I took it from the mattress maker, Grey—the rent, 8s. 6d. a week, was paid regularly.

Cross-examined by MR. GEOGHEGAN. A young man was with Jones when he came to take the house—the young man did not give his name—I never heard it—Jones said "Have you a house in Warple Way?"—I said "Yes"—he said "What is the rent?"—I said "8s. 6d. per week"—" How many rooms are there?"—I think I told him—he said he would go and see it, and if it suited him—he was away two hours or less; then he said he would take it—the young man was still with him—I cannot say I have seen the young man since—the police did not show me the man they detained—I let the house to Jones—the entry in my rent
book is to Jones—I cannot remember how the 8s. 6d. was paid; I might have given change—I am positive Jones paid it.

Cross-examined by MR. RIBTON. I have seen palliasses—I cannot say they were made there—I saw shavings and the frame they are stuffed in every time I went—I saw no tools—I may have seen three palliasses outside when I called for the rent—Gray has asked me for orders—I never saw any straw there—I have a doubt as to whether palliasses were made there.
Re-examined. I saw no women sewing with needles and thread, nor anything of the kind—the first name in the rent-book may have been a former tenant; after that it is always Jones.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . I have seen everything that has been produced, moulds, ladles, jars, bottles, &c, &c.—here is a double mould with obverse and reverse sides for half
sovereigns of 1877, two counterfeit half-sovereigns from the mould of 1878; nine double moulds, obverse and reverse sides of a half
crown of 1819, 1835, and 1846, of which the six good half
crowns found on Jones are the patterns—there are 101 counterfeit half
crowns made from these moulds—five double moulds, obverse and reverse sides of florins of 1858, 1859, and 1872, and the five good florins in the purse found on Jones are the patterns from which these are made—there are forty
two bad florins from the moulds of 1858 and 1872; not one from 1859—the five treble moulds for shillings 1844, 1860, 1863, 1865, and 1866; the five good shillings found in Jones's purse are the patterns for these moulds, with the exception of 1863—there are nineteen complete moulds, and altogether, with those broken, 100 moulds—moulds may be used a great many times before they break—then there are four batteries with everything complete, two good florins which are used in the batteries for the purpose of facing the coins, heaps of paper used for wrapping up counterfeit coin, and a lamp for colouring them after they come from the battery—they are blackened and afterwards rubbed—all these articles produced are used in the manu
facture of coin on a very large and extensive scale.
The Prisoners' Statements before the Magistrate. Jones says; "I deny saying

I was the landlord of the house, which I can prove I was not. I did not take the house. Of course I shall be able to subpœna the landlord who let the house to prove who took the house, and that was not me. I occupied three rooms on the bedroom floor and the front room upstairs, and Jones, who took the house, occupied the other part." Greenwood:

"I reserve my defence." Grey says: "I have a brother here that I have told I am not myself before I got into this trouble. I am dead; next door to it. I am like a balloon carried about the street. I have no thoughts, words, ways, or actions of my own. I have been in a lunatic asylum." Cummings says: "I have no wish to say anything. "

p.hi: In his defence Grey said he had undergone a sentence of seven years, and made a long statement about his sufferings from invisible enemies, and said he went to this house for orders and to deliver mattresses, and thought the money found on him was good. He had told his sister he was not accountable for any trouble he might get into.—Cummings said that he had never been in the house before.

div1.p:
GUILTY . JONES*†—
Ten Years' Penal Servitude.
GREENWOOD—
Seven Years' Penal Servitude.
GREY*—
Fifteen Months' Hard Labour.
CUMMINGS**—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour.

378.
JAMES MARSHALL (43),
Unlawfully attempting to utter a counterfeit shilling.

ELIZABETH WILD . I keep a refreshment shop at 32, Redcross Street—on 24th January, a little after 10 p. m., I served a man with a pennyworth of eels—he tendered what I took to be a shilling—I gave him 11d. change and put it on a shelf at the back—the prisoner came in then, and the men spoke to each other—the prisoner tendered another coin for a penny
worth of eels—I took it to my husband, who ran and stopped the prisoner—I then said "I have one very much like it," and put the other coin on the counter—the prisoner picked the first coin up and chucked down a penny—the other man had run away directly I had given him change—the prisoner tried to get away—the coin I gave my husband was like this, but much whiter.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I became aware the coins were bad before you left the shop—I am sure you spoke to the other man—you were close to him.

CHARLES WILD . On 24th January the prisoner came to our shop and put down what appeared to be a shilling—my wife served him with a pennyworth of eels—my wife took up the coin, looked at it, and showed it to me—I saw it was bad—the prisoner stood there eating his eels, the other man ran out—I shut the shop door and said to the prisoner "You will not go out"—he struggled with me, we were up and down five or six times—I said "It is no use your trying, you don't go outside of my door till a policeman comes"—he said he would pay his penny, it was not his shilling—when a constable came I gave him into custody—I gave the coin to the constable—the prisoner took up the coin which my wife put on the counter—I think he put it in his mouth, it was not left in the shop.
EDWIN REEVES (Policeman M 257). I was called to this house about 10.30 on 24th January—I found the prosecutor detaining the prisoner—

the prosecutor gave him into my charge, and at the same time handed me this coin; it has been since in my possession—the prisoner said, "I did not give it him; the other man gave it him"—I searched him in the shop; I found sixteen sixpences, three threepenny pieces, and 1s. 5d. in coppers, good money, no bad coin—this coin looked brighter then, and like a good shilling.

WILLIAM WEBSTER . This coin is a Hanoverian medal ground down, leaving a portion of the Victoria: the Hanover and George and Dragon being obliterated; it is then silvered over by some mineral powder—it would look like an ordinary worn shilling, and would be more dangerous than an ordinary counterfeit coin because you cannot bend it; it is like brass—it is not worth a farthing.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not tender the shilling, but paid my penny, when I was stopped and accused, but I had not seen it before.

GUILTY. —
Six Months' Hard Labour.

379.
HENRY HEALEY (25)
, Feloniously marrying
Margaret Peavoy during the life of Sapphire his wife.

MR. MONTAGU WILLIAMS
Prosecuted; MR. HOFFMEISTER Defended. ANNE POOLE. I am the daughter of Thomas Poole, and live with my father at Park Street, Liverpool—I have a sister, Sapphire Healey—in 1876 I was living with my father at 2, Charrington Square, Barracks Town, Cork—my sister was then a widow named Sykes; she had been a widow 10 years—I knew Sykes perfectly; he went to Chicago—my sister received two letters; the first said he was doing well; the next was of his death—we always burn letters—my sister went into the service of Mr. Stewart, the Magistrate of the village; that was in 1869—my sister did not go into mourning for him—we have not heard of Sykes from that day—I was present on 23rd June when my sister was married to the prisoner—this is the certificate—they lived together four months, when the prisoner was ordered to India—I saw my sister Saphire four days ago; she was in perfect health.

Cross-examined. I think my sister was married to Sykes in 1865—he was an engineer; he worked at Cork—they had one child, which was born about 10 years ago; it is now in heaven—we got one letter from Sykes; my sister never answered him; I do not know why—the child lived with my sister'; she was called Matilda Sykes—my sister wrote to him for money; she told him he was only a husband in name, and she could have nothing more to do with him; we never heard since—I saw three letters from the prisoner—my sister went to service at several places; she was never out of the country; she lived in Cork—I went to Liverpool nearly six years ago—I have seen all the letters. Re-examined. We received the letter announcing Sykes's death in 1870—the first letter came from Chicago; the second from Tasmania, from the person with whom he was living. MARGARET PEAVOY. I am an inmate of Epsom Union—I am a widow—my maiden name was Lyons—on 22nd May, 1880, I went to live in Brook Street, Exeter—I was married on 21st May, 1880, to the prisoner—this is the certificate.
Cross-examined. Before that I was married at Stirling in Scotland—I met the prisoner on board a ship coming home from India—he was in

soldiers told me he was a married man—he said that his wife'died of small-pox in France—he did not tell me he had written to her three times in September, October, and November, 1679, and all the letters had been returned—we arrived in England on 18th April, 1880—we went from Southampton to Exeter, where I was married to the prisoner—we had been in England a month and two days—we made inquiries after his first wife, and that made me think he was married, and I applied to the War Office—I am prosecuting—I was before the Magistrate—the charge was dismissed because I had no money to pay for it—there is one child of the marriage, born on 11th May last in the Union—I knew the prisoner's mother—I did not know she made inquiries—he showed me a pocket ledger, and I saw the name scratched out—my first husband was a soldier—I did not know that the prisoner went through the Afghan war, only what he told me—I did not know he had a medal.

WILLIAM FLOYD (Police Inspector). I arrested the prisoner on February 18th at 20, Nelson Street, Brighton, on a warrant—I read the warrant to him—he said,?" You cannot find her; I do not know that she is alive"—the charge was bigamy.
Cross-examined. I was in charge of the first case; it was'dismissed—I know nothing against the prisoner's character.

p.hi: submitted that there was no evidence of the death of the first wife. The
held that as the letter announcing the death would not be admissible, secondary evidence was not, therefore there was no evidence to go to the Jury.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

380.
DONATO MAGRINO (14)
PLEADED GUILTY
to two indictments for unlawfully wounding
Alfred Larking and
Walter Evans on 26th February .—
To enter into his own recognisances and two sureties of 20l. each to come up for judgment when called upon.

381. The said
DONATO MAGRINO was again indicted
on two in
dictments for feloniously wounding
Alfred Larking and
Walter Evans. No evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

382.
WILLIAM BATCHELOR (31)
PLEADED GUILTY
to feloniously marrying
Elizabeth Ann Buckett during the lifetime of his wife.—
Eighteen Months' Hard Labour. ,

383.
PERCY BRAYE (22)
, Embezzling 16s. 91l. 2d., 1l. 10s. 91l. 2d., and 17s. 6d. received by him for and on account of
Edward Hayward, his master.

JOHN GRUB . I am an engineer, and live at 2, Ewark Road, Forest Hill—my wife keeps a small general shcp—the prisoner came to me shortly before Christmas, and I gave him an order for 4 lb of butter—I knew he was in Hay ward's employ ment—I paid for that butter—three or four days afterwards I gave him another orders—I took an account from him for the goods—I produce the receipts I got from him for 16s. 9 1/2 d. on 6th January, 1l. 10s. 9 1/2 d. on 13th January, and 1l. 14s. 6d. on 17th January.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I was a ready-money customer at the shop—it was about 9 p.m. when I paid 1l. 10s. 9 1/2 d.—the goods were delivered within the week—I always pay cash. Re-examined. I got the receipts at my own house. EDWARD HAYWARD. I carry on business at Spencer Road, Forest Hill—the prisoner came into my employment at the end of November—he did general work in the shop, and solicited orders out
doors—money taken at the counter would go into the till without restriction—money taken out of doors would be paid in the evening to Mrs. Hayward or me, and a signa-ture given for it—there is no entry of 16s. 9d. on 6th January, or 1l. 10s. 91/2d. on 13th January received from Mr. Grub—I did not know Mr. Grub.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. You were about three months in my employ—I received a five years' character with you—my gross takings from 9th to 14th January were 57l. 19s. 10d.—18l. 11s. 9d. was in bills paid—the Saturday's takings were 17l. 18s., leaving 20l. for the other five days—I said before the Magistrate that my grocery ready-money averaged 2l. 10s.—if a person pays the same day no entry is required; if paid the following day the cash is entered in this book, and credited after office routine—Hilton left me on 11th February because he was associated with you—except that I dismissed him I have no part in his non-appear-ance to-day—I did not know he was to give evidence.

Re-examined. From inquiries I made about the prisoner's character through Messrs. W. A. Gilby of their agents in Hull, Messrs. Catley and Percival were in business in a small way for four years, and only twelve months ago were partners—they kept no assistant—the prisoner's character purported to be for five years with that firm—Mr. Grub's name does not appear in my book at all; nor Mr. Dye's—they were secret transactions.

By the Prisoner. The goods were delivered surreptitiously at meal times, against the rule of the house—you were in the shop the whole day once a week—I did not offer to withdraw from the prosecution before the Magistrate; I said I should be glad if the Magistrate was able to deal with it, whereupon your Counsel said "Perhaps you would like to withdraw?" and my answer was "Certainly not. "

GEORGE KIDD (Policeman P 403). I took the prisoner into custody at the Charing Cross Hotel on 27th January—I told him he would be charged with embezzling sums of money amounting to 4l. from his employer, Mr. Hayward—he said u I paid all the money in. "

WILLIAM SAMUEL DYE . I live at 3, Stanley Villas, Forest Hill, and am a grocer—on a Tuesday in January I had from Mr. Hayward through Braye a hundred-weight of sugar—he was round soliciting orders—I afterwards purchased a half hundred-weight of sugar—that came to 1l. 17s. 6d.—my wife paid 1l., and I paid 17s. 6d. to the prisoner.

Cross-examined by the Prisoner. I paid it at the shop over the counter——I took no receipt—I considered it a cash transaction—I saw you put it in the till—no one else was in the shop—I know Hilton—he has said he saw Mr. Grub pay moneys, and I understood him to say he had seen moneys paid into the till that had been received from Mr. Grub.
By the JURY. The day I paid the 17s. 6d. was not the day I had the goods.

Re-examined. Hilton told me about these payments before he was dis
charged—I have not seen him since he was discharged.

Prisoner's Defence, The transactions were cash, and therefore not entered. It was impossible for me to pay money in I received at 9 p.m., when the prosecutor lives at a private house. He offered to withdraw from the prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, MARCH 27TH, 1882.
